content.body: Maybe this proposal is pointing to a need to split off accessor from the decorators proposal so that it's not blocked on them?
`accessor` is sort of split off. It was originally introduced in Grouped and Auto-Accessors and brought over to decorators to meet implementor requirements
content.formatted_body: accessor is sort of split off. It was originally introduced in Grouped and Auto-Accessors and brought over to decorators to meet implementor requirements

nicolo-ribaudo: Which syntax were you talking about the one on the slide now with the decorator?
content.formatted_body: nicolo-ribaudo: Which syntax were you talking about the one on the slide now with the decorator?

content.body: The one with the validate keyword
Or the `class Foo { accessor x = 2; }` syntax?
content.formatted_body: Or the class Foo { accessor x = 2; } syntax?

content.body: I meant that `class Foo { validate x(val) { ... } }` looks a lot like `class Foo { set x(val) { ... } }`, so I'd expect similar performance
content.formatted_body: I meant that class Foo { validate x(val) { ... } } looks a lot like class Foo { set x(val) { ... } }, so I'd expect similar performance

content.body: I'd also expect similar perf with the decorator example, since I'm literally seeing a function attached to the property
I would have less of that expectaton for a plain `accessor x = 2`, but I guess most times you'd want to decorate that anyway
content.formatted_body: I would have less of that expectaton for a plain accessor x = 2, but I guess most times you'd want to decorate that anyway

content.body: I wonder if `accessor x = 2` is more optimizable though, since there is no user code running there even if it's a get/set pair
content.formatted_body: I wonder if accessor x = 2 is more optimizable though, since there is no user code running there even if it's a get/set pair

Ok I think I was mostly focusing on the second use case, I'm not sure I agree with the first one
only for the use cases where the instance shape is needed from outside
For this could we have a bult-in `@public` decorator, with the decorators metadata proposal?
content.formatted_body: For this could we have a bult-in @public decorator, with the decorators metadata proposal?

true - and a class decorator could do it all in one

content.body: Are people realistically going to add the mental overhead of figuring that out though? My assumption would be that codebases that don't particularly care about performance would just apply it everywhere
sure but if they donâ€™t care about performance then it doesnâ€™t matter there, right?
_we_ care about performance even if they don't
content.formatted_body: we care about performance even if they don't

content.body: "people are not thinking about what things make their code slow" and "people want their code to be fast" unfortunately have a large intersection
we should design the language such that even people who don't care about performance end up on the happy (= reasonably performant) path
fair
New features aren't necessarily free, especially when we implement whole new capabilities to the language.

I'm looking at my accessors usage, and they are (numbers are not measured):

- 15% lazy initial computation
- 10% validation
- 5% other

content.body: Some feedback that was shared at last plenary is that class fields should behave similarly to properties defined in the constructor
You could add a proxy trap for it like `apply`/`construct`
content.formatted_body: You could add a proxy trap for it like apply/construct

content.body: I don't necessarily agree with that position, though I do agree you shouldn't be able to just grab them via `getOwnPropertyDescriptors`.
content.formatted_body: I don't necessarily agree with that position, though I do agree you shouldn't be able to just grab them via getOwnPropertyDescriptors.

content.body: Yeah I have similar usage, and I think lazy init is especially hard to expresss even with current decorator proposal.

Force it to become accessor have performance result (To be clear, I don't care much about perf issue, but I always hear some delegates attack some proposals use this reason).

Oooh yes, lazy init is another big one.

While most things can be done with decorators, I suspect alias accessors likely would need _some_ syntax if we want to support private members. And property chains would be a lot elegant as an actual language construct (like in `delete`) as opposed to e.g. an array of property names.
content.formatted_body: While most things can be done with decorators, I suspect alias accessors likely would need some syntax if we want to support private members. And property chains would be a lot elegant as an actual language construct (like in delete) as opposed to e.g. an array of property names.

content.body: To be honest, my question is, whether decorator could really go to stage 4, considering the position of browser vendors? (If there was any news on that, pls tell me...)

Another advantage of the decorators direction is that it's a lower-cost way to prototype and test the waters. E.g. if this ends up being used tremendously much, we could introduce a syntax-level solution *down the line*. For this alone, I'm actually now myself in favor of the decorators direction
content.formatted_body: Another advantage of the decorators direction is that it's a lower-cost way to prototype and test the waters. E.g. if this ends up being used tremendously much, we could introduce a syntax-level solution down the line. For this alone, I'm actually now myself in favor of the decorators direction

content.body: Which paragraph?

hax (HE Shi-Jun): it doesn't need to, it could be `let { lazy } = SomeObject` and then just `@lazy(init) accessor x` . I'm less worried about O(1) DX issues, it's the O(N) (per property) DX issues that are the main problem
content.formatted_body: hax (HE Shi-Jun): it doesn't need to, it could be let { lazy } = SomeObject and then just @lazy(init) accessor x . I'm less worried about O(1) DX issues, it's the O(N) (per property) DX issues that are the main problem
